topic_metadata.title: How to emphasize an important equation, in LaTeX's \boxed fashion?

posts.name: Jonas Bloch
posts.cooked:
Hello!

I was wondering if there was a simple way to emphasize the content of an important equation, something like LaTeXâ€™s \boxed function. I tried using #rect here and there:

#set math.equation(numbering: "(1.1)")
#rect[
  $ integral_(-oo)^(+oo) e^(-x^2) upright(d)x  = sqrt(pi) $
]

But I do not really like the box being this big, as it must contain the whole equation line, including the number. Besides, if I want to select a specific part of the equation, the following

$ integral_(0)^(+oo) e^(-x^2) upright(d)x  = #rect[$sqrt(pi)/2$] $

Is not very satisfying, as I must leave display mode in the rect and the rect borders touch the equation content. Well, I could use display and try to add some padding, but this seems like more inconvenient than necessary. Did I miss a super simple solution?

Thanks in advance for helping out!

Hello!

I was wondering if there was a simple way to emphasize the content of an important equation, something like LaTeX's `\boxed` function. I tried using `#rect` here and there:
```typ
#set math.equation(numbering: "(1.1)")
#rect[
  $ integral_(-oo)^(+oo) e^(-x^2) upright(d)x  = sqrt(pi) $
]
```
But I do not really like the box being this big, as it must contain the whole equation line, including the number. Besides, if I want to select a specific part of the equation, the following
```typ
$ integral_(0)^(+oo) e^(-x^2) upright(d)x  = #rect[$sqrt(pi)/2$] $
```
Is not very satisfying, as I must leave display mode in the `rect` and the rect borders touch the equation content. Well, I could use `display` and try to add some padding, but this seems like more inconvenient than necessary. Did I miss a super simple solution?

Thanks in advance for helping out!

posts.cooked:
This is indeed a surprisingly non-trivial problem, as the interaction between math content and regular content isnâ€™t optimal right now. However, there is a very useful package called mannot, which allows the kind of boxing youâ€™re looking for (and much more):

#import "@preview/mannot:0.2.2": markrect

$ integral_0^(+oo) e^(-x^2) dif x  = markrect(sqrt(pi)/2) $
posts.raw:
This is indeed a surprisingly non-trivial problem, as the interaction between math content and regular content isn't optimal right now. However, there is a very useful package called [mannot](https://typst.app/universe/package/mannot/), which allows the kind of boxing you're looking for (and much more):

```typ
#import "@preview/mannot:0.2.2": markrect

$ integral_0^(+oo) e^(-x^2) dif x  = markrect(sqrt(pi)/2) $
```

If you want a LaTeX-style \boxed function but with more control over size and padding, consider using \fbox or \colorbox from the xcolor package. For highlighting only part of the equation, \highlight from soul or \tikzmark can work.

Example using \colorbox for better spacing:

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{xcolor}
\begin{document}
\[
\colorbox{yellow}{$\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}$}
\]
\end{document}

This avoids the box touching the equation too closely. Let me know if you need finer adjustments!
